Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The buddhist friend asks to discuss a recent sermon they attended.
Story: I was just settling into my quiet corner, ready to read the sutra and reflect on the sermon my Buddhist friend had shared with me earlier. My phone buzzed. It was Alex, my old college friend, his message popping up: “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m losing my mind with this IKEA bookshelf.” I could almost hear the frustration in his words. As a friend, I knew he counted on me to help out, especially when he was stressed or overwhelmed. But at the same time, my Buddhist friend had just sent a thoughtful message, asking if I had time to discuss the sermon we both attended last weekend. He valued these conversations, and I knew how important it was to him—and to my own practice—to engage in spiritual study and reflection. I stared at my phone, feeling the pull in two directions. My heart ached with the urge to be there for Alex, but I also felt the weight of my commitment to my spiritual path and my Buddhist friend. The demands pressed in on me, and I sat there, torn, unsure which call to answer first.
